encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Camilla Octavia Iulia Titius Geminus Sylvia Caesar Chorus Byllius Plancus Agrippa Mecaenae Epilogue Combined Speech

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

sp.l: Camilla now methinks this golden time,
Inuites our mindes to bathe in streames of ioy:
See how the earth doth flourish in his prime,
Whose liuery shewes the absence of annoye.
These woods, how they bedeckt with natures pride,
Shew inwarde touche of new conceiued myrthe.
The pretty byrdes,that in their couerts hide,
(Free Cittizens,even happy from their birthe)
How they reioyce! and every sencelesse thing,
Even smiles with ioy: the earth perfumes the ayre,
The ayre, sweete Nectar to the earth doth bring,
And both with ioye, beget these children fair.
How richly nature doth her wealth enrobe:
Giuing each thing his beautie, forme and grace.
Eye-pleasing greene,circle of this our globe,
Apollos Great-myrrour of youthfull face.
Coulor of life, youthes liuerie, how delight
Dwels still with thee, whilst we, whom reason named
(But falsly namde and if I iudge aright)
Princes of all the rest that nature framed:
Still subiect are to sorrowes tyranny;
Slaues to mischance, vassals of fortunes power;
Bearing the yoake of endlesse miserie:
Faire baites of time which doth us all deuoure.
Now raisde aloft in honors highest seate,
Yet in that height far short of sweete content,
Now, throwne down headlong, be we never so great,
In gulfe of greefe,which we may not preuent.
Our pleasures, posting guests, make but small stay,
And never once look back when they are gone:
Where greefes bide long, and leaue such scores to pay;
As make us banckerout ere we think thereon.
Yet this same earth with new-borne beauties grac'd,
Doth say methinks in his dumbe eloquence:
Thus shall you spring, mongst heauenly angels plac'd,
When deaths cold winter once hath snatcht you hence.
These flowers, do bid us in their language, read
In beauties bookes, how beautie is most fraile:
Whose youthfull pride, the untimely steps doth tread,
To deaths black kingdome, darke obliuions vaile.
These natures quiristers, do plainely say,
Waste thus your time,in setting forth his praise:
Who feedes, who clothes, who fils our harts with ioye:
And from this dead earth, doth our bodies raise
Thus all their mirthe, are accents of our moane:
Their blisfull state, of our vnhappinesse,
A perfect map, where only we alone,
May see our good, but never it possesse.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Madam, as nature more than perfect is,
And far more fair, than that we fairest call:
So you as heyre apparant to her blisse,
Chiefe treasurer of her perfections all;
Will shew yourself most wise, and most diuine,
In curious search of her most hidden will;
And following but her footesteps, yet refine:
The vniuersall secrets of her skill.
Yet I admire, your Eagle-sighted eye,
Which hath truthes sun-bright cyrcle so well known :
In others worthe, discernes each Attomie,
Forgetfull most, of what is most your own.
These other creatures, have their properties,
Which shew, their Syre no niggard of his store,
But such great guiftes our mindes immortalize,
As proude ambitious self, can wish no more.
And you, great Ladie, whose high honor flyes,
With vertues winges, in admirations ayre:
Towring, an Eagles pyche,above the skies,
Where vulgar thoughts, are setled in despaire;
You, whose designes,have put out enuies eyes,
Whose lampe of vertue gives the purest light;
You, that enforce weake fame to royallize,
Such high reuolues, as far surpasse her might,
You, whose large praise, makes naked vertue lowre,
And tyres report, in painting out your storie;
You, in whose lappe doth streame the golden shower,
Of all good fortune, gracing highest glorie.
O how can you, once entertaine a thought,
That these high ioyes should stoupe to sorrowes lure?
Or how can true felicitie be brought,
The smallest touche of passion to endure?
Let those complaine, which suck misfortunes paps:
Who know nought else of vertue but the name,
Who seeming wise, are snar'd in follyes traps,
Whose rash attempts, breed swift ensuing shame.
But you heauens day-starre, piller of our blisse,
O want you ever, cloudes of discontent:
You are our ioy, we all ioyes, all should misse,
Did not your sunne-beames guild our firmament.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Did not thy true love seale this president,
I should suspect a serpent mongst the flowers:
And hardly iudge fair wordes from false intent,
Pore niggard truth, rich flattry, powres down showrs.
But loyall Ladies, do you think in faith,
That highest honor, ioyes most sweet content?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: It doth no doubt, for high, and heauenly saith
The prouerbe olde, to which I give consent.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Then hear me speak, what I shall say by proofe,
And what experience printed in my heart?
Perhaps a story for your own behoofe,
Where I myself, have played an actors part.
In youthe, I thought (though falsly thought)that best
Which fairest seemde, and my aspyring minde
Disdaind (though not with pride)that there should rest
A mean-borne thought, within my thoughts confin'd.
Treading this path, I was at last desired,
By Lord Marcellus, for his spouse, and wife.
Marcellus, he whose worthie fame aspyred,
To the highest toppe of honor, during life.
If wealth, (nurse of delight) mought breed content:
I had no want of store to make me glad:
My greatnesse did ambitious thoughts preuent:
Such high successe Marcellus honours had.
Proude Carthage knows,his youthfull sword did pay
Large tribute of their soules to stygian lake:
His middle age, the stoutest Gaules did fraye,
Marcellus name made their huge armies quake.
His ancient yeares, made craftie Hanniball
Admire the proues, and vallour of his foe:
Thrice bitter name,that cursed Canniball,
By bloudie treason, made him life forgoe.
Fiue times this cittie grac'd my worthy Lord,
Or rather he them grac'd,with Consuls name.
What they to others suites would scarce afforde,
They ioyde to see my Lord accept the same.
Now Ladies to forget my present state,
Did ioy think you this while orecharge my minde?
I ioyde I must confesse, to see how fate
With boundes of honor, had my life confin'de.
But when I found, how monster enuie, feedes
On highest honor, as his daintiest pray:
How brightest fier, great store of fuell needes,
To keepe his light, and beautie from decay.
When that I found the musicke of my minde,
Tunde to the concorde, of Marcellus blisse:
And sawe, true vallour had his life assignde,
To haughtie Mars whose course most dangerous is.
I lived in him, he spent his royall dayes,
In bloudie bosome of life-scorning warres.
Safetie may breede delight, not nourish praise;
Harde is the way, from the earth unto the starres.
Whiles thus our state, depended on his sworde,
And thousand thousands sought his finall end:
Could my true love,in all this time, afforde
One quiet thought in perfect mirthe to spend?
So many perils as on earth are found,
So many dangers as on raging seas,
So many terrours all my ioyes confound,
For true love passions are no weake disease.
But is this all? no, more if more may be,
It is greater care,to keepe, then get, a crowne.
Vertue doth raise by small degrees we see:
Where in a moment Fortune casts us down.
And surely those that live in greatest place,
Must take great care,to be such as they seem:
They are not princes, whom sole tytles grace,
Our princelie vertues, we should most esteeme.
The sandes on Neptunes shores,and beamy starres,
Do not exceede the number of those cares
Which in our mindes, do stirre up ciuill warres,
And crosse delights accountes, at vnawares.
Let this suffice, the tempest soonest teares
The highest towers, and who will mount alofte,
The more he climes, the more his footing feares:
Often he slides, but sildome falleth softe.
What words, can paint the infinite of woes?
What tongue, can half those miseries relate?
Which thundring fortune, threatned to impose
Upon my head, at Tarent, but of late.
When as mine eyes mought see though loth to see)
The sunnes, with whose eclipse, my fortune changed:
Mine own dear Lord, and brother, both to be
In mortall armes, against each other ranged.
Which tempest calm'd, the storme begins again,
On mischiefes maine, full sayles mishap doth beare:
I know not now what doth my Lord detaine,
But for I know not, I know cause to fear.
To visit him, at last I was contented,
And in those forraine coastes to make appeale:
But my accesse, at Athens he preuented,
Which makes me think, more than I will reueale.
And can I then with sorrowes waight oppressed,
Thinke to enamell my conceit with ioy?
Can I, that am with fortunes wracke distressed,
Hope to escape the Ocean of annoy?
Why, this is ioye,to taste no scence of death,
Till dying hower, have stopt our vitall breath.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: It is true delight, to know no cause of greefe,
Although the outward signes of ioye be small:
Who most reioycing, feeles that inward theefe,
A stayned conscience findes no ioy at all.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Indeede I think, true ioy, a thing seuere,
Springing from fountaine of a vertuous minde:
From spotlesse faith, and conscience pure and cleare,
The chiefest good, the heauens have us assignde.
For as some weepe, that are not passing sad:
So many laugh that are not rightly glad.
Say worthie Titius what rare accident,
In so short time, did bring to happie end,
The cruell warres; which Caesars discontent,
Gainst Lord Antonius, lately did intend;
How could so many weapons thirsting bloud,
Be satisfied with vnexpected peace?
What powerfull starres importun'd us such good?
And did their angers tyrranny suppresse?

sp.speaker: Titi.
sp.l: That will I do,my good friend Geminus
And much the sooner, for that you may know,
no force,or weapons, hath procured us,
The happy truce, wherein we glory now.
It was the time, when the declining sunne
Made greatest shew of least performed light:
And by his swift departure had begun,
To yeelde his interest, to the encroaching night.
When as the seas, even burthened with our waight,
Deliuered us unto the perfect view
Of dreadfull Tarent: where for us did waight,
Antonius fleete, with all their martiall crew.
There did our drowned anchors make us stay,
Within the iawes of dangers tyrranny:
There, we discouered by the flying daye,
The agents of our threatned misery.
Who can expresse the horror of that night,
When darkenesse lent her robes to monster fear?
And heauens black mantle banishing the light,
Made every thing in ougly forme appeare.
Until Aurora with fair purple flowres,
Like loving spouse, had strawed Tytans waye:
Whose glorious beames, began to guilde the towres,
As ioyfull post, of pleasure-bringing day.
Then did loude Martiall musicke charme a sleepe,
Each languishing conceipt, in doubtfull brest:
And new borne comfort, now began to creepe,
In every minde, with causelesse fear opprest.
Then, pride of honor, made us scorne our foes:
And courage added winges to our desire.
To present fight, we all ourselves dispose:
With bloudie showers, to quenche incensed ire.
But ere our armies, had their charge fulfild,
Ere weapons, had our inward rage exprest:
Loe where Octavia comes into the field,
Betwixt both our armies, she herself addrest.
Where with the Nectar of her eloquence,
With words that mought relent indurate frost:
With maiestie, and beauties influence,
She stayes our Captaines, and affronts each hoast.
O how I see that wonder-breeding face!
O how I hear those hart-enchaining wordes!
O face! o wordes! that merite highest grace!
Immortall sure, base earth none such affords,
No womans weapon blindes her princely eye;
No womans weakenesse,her tongues passage stayes:
Like one, that did both death, and fate defie,
Minerua-like she stands, and thus she says.
Here will I bide, and this same brest oppose
To all your weapons, and whose wicked hand,
Shall first beginne to assail or strike his foes,
Shall strike this heart, and breake this vitall band.
No bloudie deed, Octaviaes eyes shall gaine,
A witnesse of your loathed crueltie:
But through this body shall the first be slaine,
That in this battle, is compell'd to dye.
If honor, vertue, worthe, or pietie,
Liue in your mindes, which beare such loftie names:
Returne your weapons, and here quietly,
With reason, quench the force, of angry flames.
Else, let some bloudie executioner,
First robbe this iealious tombe, of loathed life:
And then, no longer need you to deferre,
The issue, of your more than mortall strife.
Much more she said ,which none but she can say,
And with her sugered speech, so much preuaild,
That like Medusaes marbled creatures, they
Amazed stood, so was their furie quaild.
Looke how that trident scepter bearing king,
His ofte rebelling subiects, doth suppresse,
And with a sodaine becke in order bring,
Their disproportion, with a quiet peace;
When that the pride, of some truce-wanting storme,
Doth summon up their treason-working power;
Now gracing terror, with huge mountaines forme,
Now with steepe whirlepoole, seeking to deuoure:
So stood the Emperors, with her wordes amazed,
Her words, which seemde the myrrour of her deede.
As men inchanted so on her they gazed,
And in her face, new lectures ganne to reede.
But when she saw, her words did take effect,
Then powrde she forth the quintessence of witte:
And never did her enterprice neglect,
Till both the Emperours bewitcht with it;
Not only, did forget all former hate,
But even there, before Octaviaes face,
A league of friendship they did consumate,
And louingly each other did imbrace.
O what a ioyfull sight, it was to behoulde
A dangerous fight, turn'd to a daintie feast.
To see how friends salute each other could,
That but even now, each other did detest.
There did both armies sport in great delight,
And enterchangeably their loves expresse:
As captiues, foild without bloud, wound or fight,
They praise the conquest, and the victor blesse.
Then did Antonius, for Octaviaes sake,
Giue unto Caesar twentie Brygantines:
Which Caesar did in courteous manner take,
And in requitall of his kinde designes,
Did twice fiue hundred armed soldiers, give
To Anthony and quickly one mought finde,
The sparkes of emulation made them striue,
Who mought do most, to please Octaviaes minde.

sp.speaker: Gem.
sp.l: O noble deed, deseruing highest praise,
Well worthye to out-liue all memorye:
Life-sauing Empresse, how thy wisdome staies,
Even swarmes of soules, from Plutoes tyranny.
But why did not Antonius in like sorte
Returne to Roome to pay delight her due.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: He presently towards Parthia did resort,
Against their King the warres for to renue.
And recommending all his own affaires,
His wife, his children, and what else was dear,
To Caesars best disposing: he repayres,
To Syria and entends to winter there.

sp.speaker: Gem.
sp.l: Roome thou that keepst, the pearle that doth enclude,
Heauens dearest treasure, in earths finest frame:
Be never so vngratefull, to obtrude
Night-blacke obliuion, to her noble name.
Come Geminus and unto me relate,
What made the Empresse, alter her entent:
What did your voyage thus abbreuiate,
And all your expectations preuent.
Fame (bad concealer of our close entents)
Said, that the Empresse would to Syria go:
To see Antonius who himself abscentes,
But your returne, doth shew it was not so.

sp.speaker: Gem.
sp.l: Madame, when Aeolus had once conuai'd
Our moouing houses, unto that same place,
Where noble Cecrops the foundations lay'd,
Which are the Grecian confines chiefest grace:
There, long before we could approach the gates
Of that fair Citty, we encounter'd were,
With people of all ages, and estates,
Who in their handes, did boughes of Lawrell beare.
Some on their knees, with ioy, and wonder fil'd,
Salute the Empresse: some rich giftes present.
Some straw'd the way with flowers, and some distil'd
Their sweet perfumes, along the fields we went.
Thus to the Citty were we guarded straight,
Where for our coming, all the states awaite.
There were our eyes, inuited to beholde
Most sumptuous shewes, with many pleasing sights:
There did we hear, their learned tongues vnfolde.
The muses skill, with rauishing delightes,
Their lowd applause, which peirc'd the very skies,
Extolde Octavia past the reach of fame:
And silent Eccho wakened with their cries,
Taught all the neighbour hylles, to blesse her name.
Thus frankly did two daies themselves bestow,
To gratifie our entertainement there:
Whiles Antonie who as it seem'd did know
Of our approach, and thereof stood in fear:
Sent Niger unto Athens with all speed,
Who to Octavia letters did conuay:
Requiring her no further to proceede,
But for his coming in that place to stay.
For thither meant he shortly to repayre,
And therefore would not, she should vndertake
So long a iorney, which mought much impayre
Her health, and quiet, bootlesse for his sake.
She, half suspecting (as there was good cause)
That this was but a practise of delay:
Although vnwilling, yet she made a pause,
As one that knew not how to disobay.
But finding all his words to want effect,
And seeing nothing mought his minde recall:
Such things, she doth unto him straight direct,
As she had brought, to pleasure him withall.
Which was, two thousand chosen men at armes:
Great store of horses, wonte to winne their price;
Much armour, to defend themselves from harmes,
As richely wrought, as cunning could deuize;
Guiftes, to reward his best-deseruing friends;
A summe of money for his souldiers paye;
And briefly all her care, and studie bends,
To saue his wayning honor, from decaye.
But when she saw, nought mought his thoughts recline
Vnkinde,saith she, sencelesse of thine own shame,
I will be myself, since thou wilt not be mine:
Thus she concluded, and away we came.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: O peerelesse paragon! O natures pride!
Faire Cabinet, where wisdomes treasure lies,
Earths glory, and the heauens beloued bride,
Rich seate of honor, vertues paradize.
Most noble Empresse, praise of women kinde,
Whose faith endures the rage of fortunes flame:
Whose constant truthe, and truly vertuous minde,
Scornes smallest touche of iust-deserued blame.
How naturall, and vndeuided, are
The sparkes of honor, in a noble harte:
How industrie, and wit, may not compare,
With that true touche, our birthright doth imparte.
Liue vertuous Empresse, myrrour of our age,
Though chance discharge whole vollyes of reproach;
With fortitude withstand proud fortunes rage,
Let not despaire, near thy sweete thoughts encroache.
Time must needs turne thy mourning unto ioye,
For true delight from hence his spring doth take:
When we with patience suffer sharpe annoye,
Not for our merits, but for vertues sake.
Heauens hear poore earth complaine,
How we, your frownes do beare:
When all things else reioyce,
Ioye scornes with us to dwell.
And reasons self can tell,
Each mirthe discouering voice,
Assures our iudging eare,
How all things else want paine:
Scence-following creatures know
No cause, why to lament,
In them, remorse doth sowe,
No seedes of discontent.
We see, and know, but wante our blisse:
Vnperfect nature causeth this.
Yea nature most vnkinde,
Contriuer of our fall:
Begins our life with teares,
And ends the same with woe.
Greefe (pleasures mortall foe)
Confounds our hope with feares:
And sowers our sweete with gall.
This Tyrant of the minde:
By reason, wit, or skill,
Can never be withstood:
These aggrauate our ill,
By shewing what was good.
And wante of that torments us most:
Whose worthe appeares in being lost.
Were nature falsely nam'd
A stepdame to mankinde,
That sexe, which we account
Vnperfect, weake, and fraile,
Could not in worthe preuaile:
And men so far surmount.
We should Octauia finde,
In some sorte to be blam'd.
She winnes immortall fame,
Whiles he who should excell:
Dishonour'd hath his name,
And by his weaknesse fell.
For double shame he doth deserue,
Who being guide doth soonest swarue.
And Lorde Antonius thou
Thrice woman conquered man:
Shall not thy heart repine,
Their triumphs to adorne?
Octauiaes vertues scorne,
That wanton life of thine:
And Cleopatra can,
Commaund thy ghost even now.
And faine would I refraine,
From Fuluiaes stately name:
Which doth thy manhood slaine,
And makes thee blush for shame.
In this one thing, yet happie mayst thou be:
They Princesse are, that triumph over thee.
Dwell in fames living breath,
To eternity resign'de,
Ye fair Mars-conquering wights:
And fear not Lethes floud,
Your vertues always bud,
Your storie, honour wrights,
And Phoenix-like you finde,
A new life in your death.
Arme but your Angel-soules,
With perfect vertues shield,
That Thanatos controules,
And makes Erynnis yeelde,
Then shall the heauens your worthe descrye:
Earth, sing your praise, and so will I.
O thrice and foure times, happie messenger,
Hast thou from Parthia made returne of late?
Canst thou declare the issue of the warre,
And make me know, Antonius happie state?
What causd my Lorde in Syria make such staye,
Since he against Parthia did his forces bende?
When doth he meane, towards Roome to take his way?
And to those warres, impose a finall end?
Vnkinde he is:not so, but distant far,
And his great trouble, much my good impayres:
Else would he not mine eares so long time barre,
From much expected newes of his affayres.

sp.speaker: Byl.
sp.l: Madame, these eyes have seen what hath been done
In Syria, Parthia and each other place;
I present was, when Lord Antonius wonne
Eighteene great battles, in a little space.
I often sawe, when mischiefe, in the fielde
Had all her force against my Lorde brought forthe:
How he with vallor, made even fortune yeelde,
And chance, awaight on well approued worthe.
I was in Media when Phraortes slue
Great Tatianus fighting for my Lorde:
I sawe when he our engins from us drew,
And put ten thousand Romaines to the swoord.
I was in presence, when a sodaine fear,
In blackest horrour of the darkest night,
So much astonisht all that present were,
With shriking cries that mought even stones affright:
That Antony with fear of treason mooued,
Made Ramnus humbly sweare upon his knee,
To strike that head, that head so much beloued,
From off his shoulders, when he once should see,
Vneuitable danger, to lay holde,
Upon himself; yet could not all this, quaile
His haughty courage, but as vncontroulde,
He still proceedes, his stoutest foes to assail .
And having now, sum'd with the Parthian blood,
The largest scores, of wrongs we did sustaine,
Thence to retyre, he now hath thought it good:
And for a time at Blanckbourg to remaine.
Blanckbourg a Citty near to Sydon plac'd,
Unto the which our whole Campe did resorte,
There he entends to stay, and not in haste
To visite Roome as most of them report.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: O what should moue my Lord thus long to stay?

sp.speaker: Byl.
sp.l: An others tung mought better it bewray.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: What dost thou know more than thou hast yet said?

sp.speaker: Byl.
sp.l: Madame no more.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Why then am I dismaide?
Why do I see thy sorrow-clowded brow,
Seeme to conceale I know not what annoy?
Say Byllius whence those troubled looks may grow?
Is my Antonius safe? doth he enioy
That body free from hurt, wound or disease?
Doth he yet live and draw his vitall breath?
Speake, quickly speak, truth cannot me displease,
Where now suspition wounds as deepe as death.

sp.speaker: Byl.
sp.l: It cannot be but that your grace doth know,
For what can be conceal'd from Princes eare?
And further speech mought seedes of discord sow,
Betweene your highnes and my Lord I fear.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: O how delay torments a doubtfull minde.
I know, no, he procures I may not hear
Of anything from thence, whereby I finde,
Although vnknowne yet double cause of fear.
Then banish doubt, and see thou plainely tell,
What strange occasion doth enforce his stay?
What can Antonius princely minde compell,
In forraine coastes to make so long delay?

sp.speaker: Byl.
sp.l: Madame, the cause that made him to remaine
In Syria so long time when as we went
Towards Parthia is the same that doth detaine,
His highnesse now and thus your grace preuent.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Am I an Empresse still thus disobay'd?
And dost thou dare to dally with me still?
I first enquir'd, what him in Syria staide.
Why dost thou fear to tell the worst of ill.

sp.speaker: Byl.
sp.l: If this likewise be hidden from your grace,
In humble sort a pardon I beseech:
That high displeasure against me take not place,
For what shall be disclosed by my speech.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: I pardon all, so long as all be true.

sp.speaker: Byl.
sp.l: Who doth delude let sharp death be his due.
Then if you list the truth to vnderstand,
The truth is this:that fond AEgiptian Queene,
Queene Cleopatra doth your will withstand,
And him detaines, who else had present been.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: By force?

sp.speaker: Byl.
sp.l: O no, worlds could not him constraine
To stay this long in any place by force:
But his affection is the loving chayne,
That from your highnesse doth his minde diuorce.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: What chilling fear doth streame along these vains?
What frozen terror makes me thus to quake?
What monstrous greefe, what horror, thus constrains
My stiuing heart, his lodging to forsake?
Tell me, from what conceipt may this be guest?

sp.speaker: Byl.
sp.l: They live together, who knows not the rest.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: I must beleeue it sore against my will.

sp.speaker: Byl.
sp.l: Hardly we credit what imports our ill.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: But slow beleefe from wisdome doth proceed.

sp.speaker: Byl.
sp.l: But mortall wounds of present cure have need.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Some fond report hath made thee falsly deeme.

sp.speaker: Byl.
sp.l: I shunne report, and lightly it esteeme,
But this I sawe, when we to Syria came,
Antonius straight to Cleopatra sent,
A messenger Fonteius was his name:
Whose swiftnes did even haste itself preuent.
More, then we knew not, but within short space
Came Cleopatra royally attended,
And met directly at the appointed place,
Which for their stay they had before pretended.
There did they sporte a time in great excesse
Of all delights which any eye hath seen,
And there Antonius his great love to express
Did frankely give to this AEgyptian queene,
Phoenicia, Cyprus and Cylicia
Part of Arabia where those people dwell
Cald Nabatheians part of Syria
And finding that she could preuaile so well
With Antony she further did proceed,
And begd part of that land we Iewry call.
From whence mought be transported at her need,
True balme, for to preserue her grace withall.
This done, my Lord, towards Parthia took his way,
Which we with fier and sworde did waste and burne,
But in those confines did not long time stay,
But back again to Blanckbourge we returne.
From whence, a poste was speedily addrest,
For to conduct this Cleopatra thither:
She kindly condiscends to his request,
Thus there they met, and there they live togither.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: O what hart-piercing greefe doth then torment,
That are thus countercheckt with riualles love?
What worlds of horror do themselves present,
Unto their mindes that do like passions proue?
O Ielousie, when truthe once takes thy part,
What mercy-wanting tyrant so seuere?
What Sylla, what Charibdis, can impart
But half those horrors which in thee appeare?
Poore Pluto why do we thy rigour dread?
All torments are containde within my brest:
Alecto doth whole troupes of furies leade
Within my soule, with endlesse greefe opprest.
O deserts, now you deserts are indeed:
Your common-wealths are coucht within my heart,
Within my heart, all rauening beasts do feede:
And with mad furie, still encrease my smart.
O greefe, I feele the worst that thou canst do.
I taste the powerfull force of mischiefes pride.
I proue the worst that chance can put me to.
The deepest wound of fortune I abide.
But staye Octavia if this be a lye:
If thy dear Lord do constant yet remaine,
Whom dost thou wrong, is it not Antony?
O fault too great, recall it back again.
Canst thou be so vnkinde, nay so vniust,
To censure, iudge, condemne without a cause?
Shall flying tales make thee so much mistrust,
Him bound to thee by Gods, and natures lawes?
O traytor passion, if thou couldst subdue
Thy soueraigne reason, what ill tragedies
Wouldst thou soon acte, but Ielousie adieu,
My Lord is constant, and these are but lyes.
Did not he sweare on that our nuptiall day,
By all the sacred rights we holy deeme,
By those immortall powers which we obaye,
By all things else which dearly we esteem.
By his right hand, by this our wedding ring,
By all that mought a perfect truthe entend:
One time, one day, one hour;should surely bring,
His life, and love unto a finall end.
Did not he say, the starres from heauen should fall.
The fishes should upon the mountaines range,
And Tyber should his flowing streames recall:
Before his love should ever think on change.
But what of this? these are but only words,
And so are those which do his faith impeache.
Octauia O poore how thy state affordes,
Nought but despaire to stand within thy reache.
The seate of truthe is in our secret harts,
Not in the tongue, which falsehood oft imparts.
Haste back then Tyber to thy fountaines head,
Descend ye starres, and this base earth adorne,
Let Neptunes people on these hilles be fed,
For Antony is fled, false, and forsworne.
But it is not so, my Antony is true:
His honor will not let him basely fall.
Octauies name will faithfull love renew.
His Innate vertue will his minde recall.
As fear of torment houlds the wicked in:
So vertues love makes good men loath their sinne.

sp.speaker: Byl.
sp.l: Madam, I cannot force you to beleeue
That which I speak, but that I speak is true,
I knew too well it would your highnesse greeue,
And would be lothe your sorrowes to renew;
But would to God that all my words were lyes,
So my disgrace mought worke your sweete content;
Would this my soule mought be the sacrifice,
To reconcile his love thus fondly bent.
O vertue, thou that didst my good assure,
Arme now my soule against proude fortunes might:
Without thy succour I may not endure,
But this strong tempest will destroy me quite.
O sacred lampe, pure vertues living flame,
That never failes sweet comfort to impart:
I feele thy power and glory in the same,
I hear thee say in closset of my heart,
Octauia live, and shew thyself a Queene,
Tread thou my path, make constancy thy guide;
Let no base fear within thy minde be seen,
Let thine own foote into no errour slide;
Make thine own thoughts no witnes of thy misse;
Let thine own conscience know no cause of blame;
A bulwarke stronge, a brazen wall this is,
That will resist, both sorrow, griefe and shame.
Antonius fall, his own disgrace procures,
His is the fault, and on his head shall fall,
The storme of mischiefes deep-reuenging showers:
When thine own worth, in heauen shall thee enstall.
His is the fault, but what? mine is the wronge.
The errour his, but I endure the smart;
O vertue, if thou be so passing stronge,
Yet once again remooue this from my heart.
Why, vertue grieues but at his own disgrace,
And mindes distrest, with patience doth relieue:
With wisedomes light it still directs his pace,
And cannot fall and therefore cannot grieue.
Well griefe, I feele that thou art griefe indeed,
But patience is a prince and must not yeeld:
O sacred vertue help me at my need;
Repulse my foes with thy all mastering shield.
But what, I must not here stand and lament,
Thy deeds Octavia must approoue thy worth:
It is wisedome, must these iniuries preuent,
I will no more excuse thy wrongs henceforth.
I will seeke by all meanes thee to reconcile,
And in my thoughts reuenge shall finde no place,
But if thou needes wilt worke a thing so vile,
To seeke my ruine and thine own disgrace,
If nothing can preuaile, I will make it seen,
Thou wrongst an Empresse, and a Romaine queene.
O dear Camilla what a wofull sight,
It is to beholde the Empresse dolefull state?
Though others burthens in our eyes seem light:
Death in my heart, her griefe doth intimate.
O what exceeding pitty it is to see,
Such noble vertues nurst in wisedomes brest:
Snar'd in the trap of humaine misery,
By others basenes thus to be distrest.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Madame, the case is pittifull indeed,
And such as may relent a flinty heart:
A patient minde, must stand her grace insteed,
Till time and wisedome, may his love conuert.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: But who dares tell a Prince he goes aside?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: His conscience best, if wisdome were his guide.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: But they are great and may do what they will.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Great if much good:not great if they do ill.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: But we must yeeld to what the Prince will have.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: He is no Prince, that is affections slaue.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Be what he will his power is ouer-stronge.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Heauens will not suffer sin to florish long.
And sure who list but to beholde the end,
Shall see Antonius dearely buy his lust:
They never prosper long that leawdly spend
Their granted time, for God is not vniust.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Well, let them talk of vertue, those that list,
Of patience, iustice and of constancie;
For me, I think the Empresse sure hath mist,
The only way to cure this maladie.
By living fame that list, with pinching paine,
And starue themselves with feeding fond conceipt:
Were I Octavia I would entertaine
His double dealing, with as fine a sleight.
I would nor weep, nor waile, but soon returne
upon his head the wrongs he doth pretend:
I would compel him spite of him to learne,
It were no iest a woman to offend.
He feeles not now the griefe that makes her smart:
But I know what would touch him to the heart.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: What force, what wit, can Antony compell,
Now to forgoe his late ill-placed love?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: One nayle you see another will expel,
When nothing else can force the same to mooue.
Should he that swims in streames of sweet content,
Make his delight the agent of my paine?
No, no, he rather were a president,
How to requite him with the like again.
Had I been toucht with seence of inward greefe,
When such like chances had be-fallen me,
Or at their leisure hoped for reliefe,
When I myself, mought best my self set free:
I had been dead for many yeares agoe,
Or must have liued in endlesse misery,
But I take order not to perish so,
He shall care little, that cares less than I.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: But doth not Sylvia blush to disanull,
Her own good name, her faith, and constancie:
Doth not she fear, the wrath of heauen to pull
Upon her head, for such impietie?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: The wrath of heauen, why no, the heauens are iust,
And Iustice yeeldes a man his due desert:
Then sithe I do no iniurie, I trust
Not I, but he, for both our faults shall smart.
And for my faithe and constancie, no doubt
I will deale for that as well as others shall:
But it is most strange to see you go about,
To praise the thing that workes all womens fall.
Why constancie is that which marreth all.
A weake conceipt which cannot wrongs resist,
A chaine it is which bindes ourselves in thrall,
And gives men scope to vse us as they list,
For when they know that you will constant bide,
Small is their care, how often they do slide.
O if you would but marke the little mappe
Of my poore world, how in times swift careere
I manage fortune, and with wit entrap
A thousand such as hould these courses dear;
Then would you say you want the art of love,
For I fear nothing less than such relaps,
The forwardnesse which I in men approoue,
Most troubles me for fear of after claps.
And Lord, you cannot gouerne one alone,
When I have many subiect to my beck:
I always pleasant, you still making mone,
You full of fear, they dread my frowning check.
Nor do I maruaile, for this vnion breedes
A loathing sure, by nature unto things:
And constancie the minde with quiet seedes,
And setled quiet soon corruption brings.
Thus first we loathe, and then we straight waies hate,
When to one obiect we entend our minde:
But I with choice do still renew the state,
Of fainting love, and still new pleasures finde.
Looke how a Bee amongst the verdant fields,
From diuers flowers extracts the pleasant thyme,
Which well compounded, one sweet matter yeelds:
So do I spend my pleasure-tasting time.
I seeke not graines of gould in barraine ground,
Nor hope for fruite, when haruest is once past:
I like not where affection is not found,
If any fall, I flye from him as fast.
And surely who will taste the sweet of love,
Must not be tyed unto one poore conceipt:
One cannot worke or half his practise prooue,
Upon one minde which will be dulled straight.
But there must be an emulation plac'd,
Mongst fauourites as spur of swift desire:
By letting one still see another grac'd,
As though the on's deserts did so require.
Two at a time I seldome entertaine,
Nor one alone, but always if I might,
Whiles anyone to court me I detaine,
Some other of the crew should be in sight:
Who mought behold, how frankly I bestow,
Both smiles; and fauours, where it pleased me,
They thinking this from his deserts to grow,
Will striue for to deserue as well as he.
Thus I abound with store of proferred love,
With vowed faith, with presents and what not:
When in the end one fortune all must prooue,
And all these fauours must be cleane forgot.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: But will not all thy seruants thee forsake,
To see a ryuall such high fauour gaine?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: If any iealious foole a surfeite take,
Then thus with art I bring him on amaine.
Some extraordinary fauour falles
On him vnwares, which may new fire his minde:
Or else some trusty agent him recalles,
In secret manner thereunto assign'd;
Who tels him (as of friendship)I admire
His discontent, and my vnkindnesse blame;
How I do oftentimes of him enquire,
And still a sigh awaites upon his name.
This way I seldom faile, till at the last,
In follies lap affection hath him lull'd.
From whence with fresh desire he flyes as fast,
As if (poore foole)his wings had never been pull'd.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: But sith thy minde can never be so free,
But that affection will on thee lay holde:
That being partiall, methinks should be
A cause, that others love would soon waxe cold.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Affection, no, I know not such a thought,
That were a way to make myself a slaue:
I hate subiection and will never be brought,
What now I give, at others hands to craue.

sp.speaker: Iul,
sp.l: But yet I know some one above the rest
Is most belou'd, but that you list to iest.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: I love one most? I fauour, love, and grace,
Most everyone, whilst he in presence is:
But being gone, look who comes next in place,
he is next my heart, my course is always this.
And if that any chance to fall away,
Shall losse of him thus vexe me at the heart?
No griefe, I never meane to be thy pray,
My care and he together shall depart.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Of straying, falling, and I wot not what,
So many words hath Sylvia spent in vaine:
That time, and truth, and purpose are forgot,
To Antony let us returne again.
We speak not of thy sutors, we complaine
Of his vntruth, that second unto none,
In faithlesnes:of duety should remaine,
Forever constant unto one alone.
Of his vntruth, who hath his honor stain'd,
By base defiling of his mariage bed:
Who being vowed, and by oath detain'd,
Is false forsworn , seduc'd and fondly fled.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Why all is one, no wedlocke can compell,
No law, no fear, no reason can constraine
Our mindes, whilst we in natures castels dwell,
The pleasing course of nature to refraine.
Nature itself doth most delight in change,
The heauens, by motion do their musicke make:
Their lights by diuers waies and courses raunge;
And some of them new formes do always take.
Their working power is never always one,
And time itself least constant is of all:
This earth we see and all that lives thereon,
Without new change;into destruction fall.
Nay what is more, the life of all these things,
Their essence, and perfection, doth consist
In this same change, which to all creatures brings
That pleasure, which in life may not be mist.
Sith then all creatures are so highly blest,
To taste the sweet of life in often change:
If we which are the princes of the rest,
Should want the same, methinks it were very strange.
For proofe heereof, I need not to vnsold:
Such far fetcht secrets, scence will make it plaine.
What pleasure hath the eye, when you beholde
One only obiect:is it not rather paine?
What sweet delight doth charme the listning eare,
When only one tune it doth apprehend?
In taste and smell, like loathing doth appeare,
Whose euidence, no wit can reprehend.
Since nature then hath framed for the eye,
Such sundrie coulors to delight the same;
And for the eare such strange variety,
Of sweetest tunes, which do our musicke frame;
Such diuers meates, to please the dainty taste;
So many fauours to delight that sence;
Each other part, with diuers pleasures grac'd;
Lest want of change mought haply breed offence.
What, shall the heart the master of the rest,
Be more restrain'd than any sauage beast?
Shall not the heart, on whom all those depend,
Have greater scope than any of them all,
To taste the pleasure of each pleasing friend?
Faith mine hath had, and so it ever shall.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Peace wicked woman, nay foule monster peace
Whose very steps defile the guiltlesse earth:
Staine of thy sexe, thy poisoned speech surcease,
That hath from sinne, and wickednes, his birth.
Is it not too much to glory in thy sinne,
Leawd creature, that hast ouer-liu'd all shame?
Imbouldning others to persist therein,
When thou thy self shouldst shun and fly the same;
But thou must make the heauens a president,
For thy misdeedes, which on thy head will power,
Eternall vengeance, unless thou repent,
And stay the force of mischiefes dreadfull shower.
These moouing thinges are constant in their kinde,
Unto the end for which they were ordain'd:
Not mutable like thy vngodly minde,
Whose very thoughts with wickednes are stain'd.
Our scences their peculiar obiects have,
Whose store, and number, doth unto us shew,
How reuerently we should ourselves behaue,
Towards him whose bounty did the same bestow.
O Chastity bright vertues sacred flame,
Be never woman louely wanting thee.
Be never woman wrong'd adorn'd with thee.
Be all disgrac'd that merit not thy name.
Iulia Come we have taried here too long.
Syluia adiew in faith I wish thee well,
No honest minde I think will do thee wrong.
It is punishment enough to hang in hell.
Great guide of this same golden flame,
Which daies and times deuideth:
Whose beauty ever is the same,
And always one abideth.
Why hast thou such a monster made,
which always thus rebelleth:
And with new torments doth inuade,
The heart wherein it dwelleth.
Affection is the sauage beast,
Which always us annoyeth:
And never let us us live in rest,
But still our good destroyeth.
Affections power who can suppresse
And master when it sinneth:
Of worthy praise deserues no less,
Than he that kingdomes winneth.
Were Antony a Prince indeed,
That base affection scorned:
Him to bemone we should not need,
With vitious life deformed.
But this seducing vertues foe,
In whom all pleasure shineth:
Doth all our scences ouerthrow,
and reason vndermineth.
Who doth not ioy, when from his necke,
The yoake of bondage slideth:
And wish to live without the check,
Of him that others guideth?
Yet what more hard, than to obserue,
In such licentious pleasure:
The golden meane, which doth not swarue,
From sacred vertues measure:
Who know, and see, the way of sinne
Beset with dangers many:
Yet still persist and walke therein,
As negligent as any.
The minde with deepest wisedome fraught,
That mischiefes hand escheweth:
And enuies craft doth bring to naught,
Affections force subdueth.
The haughty heart with courage bolde,
That deaths pale face despiseth:
The Prince which scornes to be contrould;
Affections power surprizeth.
And having made itself a king,
Our minde with errour feedeth:
Till we ourselves effect the thing,
Which our destruction breedeth.
The path of errour, is so grac'd,
With sweetest seeming pleasures:
As if delight had therein plac'd,
The store house of her treasures.
But who to prooue the same are bent,
In sinfull maze encluded:
In vaine at last will sure repent,
with shamefull end deluded.
Where vertues little beaten wayes,
with diuers troubles cumbred:
Direct our steps unto true ioyes,
Amongst the Angels numbred.
O fearce desire, the spring of sighes and teares,
Relieu'd with want, impouerisht with store,
Nurst with vaine hopes, and fed with doubtful feares,
Whose force withstood, encreaseth more and more.
How doth thy pride thus torture my poore heart,
Whiles I for bodies shadowes entertaine:
And in the haruest of most high desert,
Do reape no fruite, but scorne and deep disdaine.
No fearce Hyrcanian forrest doth possesse,
So wilde a Tyger, nor no Libian coaste,
Hath ever known a greedy Lyonesse,
Rob'd of the pray which she affected most,
So beyond measure full of furious Ire,
As is the minde rob'd of his chiefe desire.
O destinies, that draw the golden twine,
Which doth conduct the neuer-tyred poste,
Why have you left vnclos'd these eyes of mine,
To see the field of all mine honor lost?
In vaine I sought a whyle, to cure the wound
With balme of hope, drawne from a constant minde,
But now the truth is manyfestly found:
I hear, I see, I know, I feele, I finde,
The shamefull wronge, the scorne and high disdaine
Which faithlesse he most falsly doth pretend,
To power on me whilst from dispaire in vaine,
With constant hope, my weaknesse I defend,
O torment, worse than deaths most bitter gall:
Worse than is found in that infernall place;
To see another glory in my fall;
To see another proud with my disgrace.
Why dost thou stay, distrest Octavia dye.
Dead to all ioyes let death thy torments end,
Who gave thee life, the same doth now deny:
And to another his affection bend.
Another doth thy interest enioy:
And yet thou liuest, and yet thou dost delay,
To calme with death the tempest of annoye,
When to disgrace thy life doth thee betray.
Dye dead Octavia. What? and basely dye?
Shall I sit down and yield myself to shame?
Shall I content myself with wronges? not I.
Reuenge Octavia or thou art to blame.
Dye never vnreueng'd of such a wrong.
My power is such that I may well preuaile
And rather than I will endure it long,
With fier and sword I will you both assaile.
My nature doth abhorre to be thus vsed,
My heart doth scorne such monstrous iniurie:
My birth, my state, disdaine to be abused,
And I will deeply score thy periurie.
Then greefe give place a while unto disdaine.
Mylde pittie, make thee wings and flye away:
And death, withdraw thy hastie hand again,
Whiles with aduantage I their debts repay.
How now Octavia whither wilt thou flye?
Not what thou mayst, but do thou what is iust:
Shall these same hands attempt impietie?
I may, I can, I will, I ought, I must,
Reuenge this high disgrace, this Caesar will,
Byrthe, nature, reason, all require the same.
Yet vertue will not have me to do ill.
Yeeld, all things yeeld, to vertues sacred name.
How then? even thus, with patience make thee strong,
The heauens are iust, let them reuenge thy wrong.
Cruell to me, selfe-wronging Antony
Thy follie shall not make Octavia sinne:
I will be as true in vertuous constancie,
As thou art false and infamous therein.
I will be as famous for a vertuous wife,
As thou notorious for so leawd a life.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: As is a sweet pearle dropping siluer showre,
Which some milde cloud down from the shadie skies
Upon the parched flowrie fields doth power:
Such is Octaviaes sight to Caesars eyes.
Hath Iasons trauaile gaind the goulden fleece,
Or hath Octavia faild of her entent?
Is Antony within the bounds of Greece
Or doth he stay at Blanckbourg malecontent?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: O Caesar how my now distracted minde
Vnites itself to render worthy thanks:
But woe is me, no way, no meanes I finde,
No hope to hide Antonius ustful prankes.
I him besought, by all that words might say,
By this same ring that knit the Gordian knot:
By all the rights past on our wedding day,
But all in vaine, for all is now forgot.
Looke how some proude hard harted mighty rocke,
Which makes the sea a mirrour for his face,
Repell's the waters with a churlish stroake,
Which mildely striue his body to imbrace:
So his indurate minde reiects my words,
And rudely makes me and my hopes forlorne,
His flinty heart naught but repulse affoords,
And my deserts returne me naught but scorne.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: Were not Octavia precious in my sight,
Whose will withstood what I did most desire:
The bloudy lynes had not been now to wrighte,
Of such reuenge as his leawd deeds require.
But worthy branch of braue Octavius lyne,
In Caesars thoughts live and predominate:
Yours is my kingdome and what else is mine,
Myself, my scepter and my royal state.
Then sith I ever graunted your request,
And let you prooue all meanes his love to winne:
Since you and we in vaine have done our best,
To stay his foote out of the sincke of sinne;
Now for my sake, if I may aught preuaile,
For dead Octavius never stained worth:
For dear Anchariaes love, and your auaile,
Excuse no more his faithlesnesse henceforth,
Yeeld but to this, live here and banish care,
Forget his name that traytor-like is fled:
Liue like a Queene, remember who you are,
And let me rouse him from his Lemmans bed.
Leaue you this house of his, and what is his,
Stand of yourself since he entends your fall:
Dishonor not your name with others misse,
If love cannot recall him terror shall.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Dishonor not my name! O Caesar no,
My miserie is not of that degree:
Wrought by my follie or forc'd by my foe,
Which mought attribute that disgrace to me.
It is paine, and greefe, to beare and suffer wrong,
But shame and sinne to him that doth the same:
True patience can mildly suffer long,
Where rage and furie do our lives defame.
It is fortitude which scornes the force of wrong,
And temperance not to be moou'd withall:
It is constancie makes us continue strong,
And wisdoms worke to free ourselves from thrall.
But I am wrong'd you say, and it is base fear.
Without reuenge to suffer iniurie:
It is cowardize vnworthy wrongs to beare,
And madnesse to give way to trecherie,
Well then, reuenge, but what? Octaviaes wrong,
Of whom? of Antony. And who is he?
Ah my dear Lord, that will returne ere long,
And hate his fall, and be most true to me.
If not, I will then reuenge, but how? with death?
He is myself, his greefe procures my paine.
With spoile and losse? O no that were not good,
By certaine losse to hope for doubtfull gaine.
How then?be false as he is most vntrue.
One wound doth not an others balme procure.
Flame is not quencht with flame, but both renue,
A double force not easie to endure.
Whence springs reuenge? from malice and disdaine:
Then speak not of it, for it is in vaine.
Earth open first thine vndeuided Iawes,
And swallow me in thine infernall wombe:
Ere willingly I swarue from vertues lawes,
Truthe my loves childbed was, truthe be his tombe.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Were Antony as loyall in his love,
As he is false forsworne, and fondly bent:
Then would I think it reason to approoue,
And highly praise your vertuous entent.
But sith he willingly doth you forsake,
And wilfully persistes to do us wrong:
High honor doth require our swords to take,
Most iust reuenge, which we may not prolong.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: His falshood doth not malice raise in me,
But rather shewes how fraile mans nature is:
An argument which bids me carefull be,
Lest I myself should likewise do amisse.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Can my perswasions then no whit preuaile?
Can my request no thought of yeelding finde?
Can you esteeme of him whose truth doth faile?
There are few women of Octaviaes minde.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Too few I grant, and therefore am I such,
And though alone, yet will perseuer still:
We imitate the multitude too much,
Most do, as do the most, and most do ill.
The number of the vertuous is so small,
That few delight to tread that loanely way:
But wisdomes heires are iealious of their fall;
And think it shamefull all should go astray.
A vertuous act seems strange in some mens sight,
Because they seldome saw the like before,
But noble mindes are carefull of the right,
And others errors make them fear the more.
How sencelesly we sleepe in follies bedde,
How few there are indeed, how all would seem
Wise, honest, iust, how fondly are we led,
To vse that least which we do most esteeme?
Then ought a prince to fear much more than any:
Lest his fault be a president to many.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: And is it vertue then to be misused?

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: To give no cause why we should be abused.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Do but consent, I will act and beare the blame.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: To give consent to sinne, is sinne and;shame.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: And is it sinne to punish leawdnesse then?

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Sinne to exulte upon repentant men.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: But he persists in hatefull trecherie.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: True love may spring from pardoned iniurie.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: How may they love, who worlds of distance part?

sp.speaker: Octa
sp.l: He is not far that is lodg'd within the heart.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: But time, and absence, will consume all love.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Soner the heart, which doth those passions proue.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Not so, no mortall darte near love is found.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: But we are mortall which endure the wound.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Yet leaue this house, if not his love deny.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: First let this soule out of his lodging flye.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Can nature then no priuiledge obtaine?
Are his deserts in such aboundant store?
Must all I do be fruitlesse and in vaine?
Antonius be your guide, I say no more.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: If that my words so much offend your minde,
O silent death, thou my best refuge art:
O breake my heart, for Caesar is vnkinde,
In silent greefe, O breake my wounded heart.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: What in a traunce? O sister, sister dear,
Light of my life, dear modell of my soule:
Hurt not yourself, O banish needlesse fear,
Woe, woe, to me, that did you thus controule:
O dear Octavia I spake but to prooue,
How far your thoughts were bent with iealousie;
To see if malice had exilde your love,
Antony To finde how you esteemd of Antony.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: O Caesar more belou'd than these same eyes,
More than the light which glads my tired life:
Do not my truly loving minde despise,
Kill not my heart with this your factious strife.
Alasse it is not his house that I respect,
His wealth, or try partite high regiment:
I would the worlds great treasurie neglect,
Rather than hazard Caesars discontent.
It is not affection that enchaines my minde,
Or partiall love that makes my faith so strong:
Too well alasse myself abusde I finde,
And this my heart too sensible of wrong.
And what is worse, this wrong so full of scorne,
As mought incense the mildest minde aliue:
To see my Lord a gracelesse Queene suborne;
And my dishonour carelesly contriue.
Nay worse than that, if worse than that may be,
No creature ever felt the like disgrace:
Each wronged wight may hope for remedie,
My shamefull storie nothing may deface.
For if my Lord would cure this wound again:
Yet woe is me, the scarre will still remaine.
In these respects, perhaps I could be brought,
To strike reuenge as deepe as any could:
I want no meanes whereby it mought be wrought,
For many thousands wish it if I would.
And what is more, myself can scarcely let:
But Caesars sworde for me would pay the debt.
But when I finde in closet of my heart,
How I have paun'd my faith to Antony,
How I have vow'd that nought but death should part
From him my love, and my fidelitie.
When that I see the vulgar peoples eyes,
Make my designes the patterne of their deeds:
How with my thoughts they striue to simpathize,
And how my misse their certaine errour breedes.
When that I finde how my departure were,
The opening of a gate to ciuill warres:
Then Atlas-like I am constrain'd to beare,
A hated hell though not the happie starres.
I will rather dye than witnesse with these eyes,
In mortall wounds and bloudie lines enrowled,
The argument of my calamities,
Whom proud mischance, vniustly thus controwled.
Shall never two such noble Emperours,
Their dearest lives aduenture for my sake:
Shall never for my sake such mightie powers,
The doubtfull chaunce of battle vndertake.
Shall never tongue recount Octaviaes errour,
An instance of his faithlesse periurie
I will rather dye the worlds vnspotted myrrour,
And with my faith surmount his iniurie.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Well sister, then I see that constancie
Is sometimes seated in a womans brest:
Your strange designes even from your infancie,
Can never without wonder be exprest.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I know not what you think of woman kinde,
That they are faithlesse and vnconstant ever:
For me, I think all women striue to finde
The perfect good, and therein to perseuer.
Even as a Torche, or Sulphure poudered light,
Whiles any nourishment maintaines his flame,
Fayles not to burne, and burning shineth bright,
Till art obscure, or force put out the same:
Such is the minde in womans brest contained,
With the true zeale of vertues love enflam'd,
We may be dead, but living never stained,
We may be wrongd, but never rightly blam'd.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Well , for yourself proceed as you think best:
Time and the heauens, must see these wrongs redrest.
Great peeres that striue with wisdoms sacred fame,
To ouer-liue all humaine memory:
Shew me, for what entent you hither came,
What causde you to reuoult from Antony?

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: By our accesse we nothing else entend,
But humbly to beseech your maiestie:
Under your gracious fauour to defend,
Our wronged selves from hatefull iniurie.
Proud Cleopatrae AEgypts craftie Queene,
Rules Antony and wrongs she cares not where:
So insolent her late attempts have been,
As no pride-scorning Romaine heart can beare.
She is become our Queene and gouernour,
And we whose courage feares the force of no man:
By seruile basenesse of our Emperour,
Must be content to stoope unto a woman.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: What Angel Queen rules those Nyleian coasts,
Whose beautie can so ouer-rule mens mindes:
What goddesse can command the man that boasts
To equall Iulius in his high designes.

sp.speaker: Plan.
sp.l: If in those guifts, by nature we enioy,
Unto Octaviaes sacred maiestie,
She be but comparable any way:
Be never Romaines so disgrac'd as we.
But for her artificiall ornaments,
For pompe, for pride, for superfluitie,
For all excesse that folly represents:
She doth exceed the height of vanitie.
Her sunne-burnt beautie cannot please his sight,
That hath a minde with any reason fraught:
But it is her Syren tongue that doth delight,
Her craftie Cyrces wit which hath him caught.
As when from Athens, Niger made returne,
And did relate the Emperesse entent,
Which he of purpose had in charge to learne:
And did her princely guifts to him present.
And further did with truth discouering words,
Octauiaes well deserued praises frame:
An argument which to that Queene affords,
A furious blast to raise a Iealious flame.
Then did she nothing vnattempted leaue,
That art mought frame, or wit mought well deuize
Which mought his minde, of reason quite bereaue:
And thus she straight began to Syrenize
She pines her body with the want of food,
That she mought seem to languish for his sake:
And by her gestures would be vnderstood,
How from his absence she her death should take.
Her deepe lamenting looks fixt in his face,
In silent termes present an earnest sute:
As who should say, O pitty my hard case,
Whom violence of passion maketh mute.
Then would she stand of purpose in his way,
In any place where he should passage make:
And there as though vnwilling to bewray,
What bitter griefe she inwardly did take:
Down from her eyes distils a Christall tyde,
Which at his coming she would dry again,
And sodainly would turne her head aside ,
As though vnwilling to reueale her paine.
Thus in his presence rauished with ioy,
She smiles, and shewes, what mirth she can deuize:
But in his absence drowned with annoy,
She seems to take her life from those his eyes.
Then Meeremaid-like his scences she inuades,
With sweetest nectar of a sugered tongue:
Unto her will, she ever him perswades,
The force of her words witch-craft is so strong.
Then came the kenell of her flattering crew,
Who largely paint the story of her death,
Like feede Atturneys they her sute renue,
And hunt Antonius spirits out of breath.
Wherewith assayl'd, he like a man enchaunted,
To make her know she need not to misdoubt him:
Or like to one with some mad fury haunted,
Assembleth all the people round about him.
In that fair Citty royalliz'd by fame,
By that great Macedonian monarke builded:
Of whom it took beginning, birth and name;
Where on a high Tribunall seate which yeelded,
A large prospect, were plac'd two chayres of golde;
One for himself, another for her grace,
And humbler seates which mought her children hold,
Of such like mettall, in the self same place.
There he establisht Cleopatra Queene
Of AEgipt, Cyrpua and of Lidia:
And that his bounty mought the more beseene,
He ioyn'd thereto the lower Syria
Caesarion heyre apparant to her grace
Was constituted King of those same lands.
His own two sons by her were there in place,
Attended with great troopes of martiall bands.
These two, the mighty Kings of Kings he called,
And to the eldest gave Armenia,
The country Media and forthwith enstalled
Him regent of the Kingdome Parthia.
To Ptolomy he gave Phoenicia
And all the terrytories there adioyning:
The vpper Syria and Cilicia,
Unto them both peculiar guards assigning.
A Median gowne the elder of them ware,
And all the Armenian souldiers so instructed:
Accomplishing the charge they had before,
About him came and thence they him conducted.
In Macedonian robes the other stands,
In distance from his brother little space:
About him came the Macedonian bands,
And guarded safe his person from the place.
These things proclaim'd, the trumpets lowdest voice,
Unto all peoples eares forth with imparted,
Whereat some frowne, some murmure, some reioyce,
Whiles he, with his immortall queene departed.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Immortall? why you said she was not such.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Not she, but her attyre did claime thus much.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: Was her attyre so admirable then?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Scorning the basenes of us mortall men.
Clad like the Goddesse Isis she did go:
Then what hard heart would not have thought her so

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: When that Apollodorus on his back,
A flockbed did to Iulius Caesar bring:
With thongs of leather trust up like a sacke;
As though there had been need of such a thing,
Where was the Goddesse when this came to passe?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: She , noble she, was ryding on her Asse.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: When Antony about the streetes doth runne,
Listning at each mans window in the night:
To hear what in the house is said or done,
And with strainge noyses passengers affright.
Where is this Goddesse then so highly blest?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: She ambles after to laugh at the iest.

sp.speaker: Cae
sp.l: And shall our state maintaine their hateful pride?
Shall bleeding Roome procure their wanton peace?
It is time we stould a remedy prouide,
And their ambition speedily suppresse.
What guilded baites of sinne,
Do still procure our misse:
And seeke our soules to winne,
From their entended blisse?
Even natures self doth draw,
And force us still to slide:
And violate the law,
Which reason makes our guide.
Of pleasures we alowe,
Which do our thraldom bring:
When starueling vertue now,
Is scarcely iudg'd a thing;
The one a poore conceipt, the other proou'd a King.
If that it be so sweete,
To tread the path of sinne:
And so exceeding meete,
We should not walke therein;
O nature most vnkinde,
That prooues weake reasons foe:
O reason too too blinde,
That crosseth nature so.
Three mal-seducing foes,
Conduct false errours traine:
Misleading most of those,
Which vertues praise would gaine.
Whose force unless we foyle, we labour all in vaine.
The examples of the most,
Which most do take least care,
To anchore on the coaste,
Where sacred vertues are.
Sweete Syrenyzing tongues,
In flattery most expert:
Whose ill perswading songes,
Our scences do peruert.
And mens iniurious deeds,
Do cause us to digresse:
Our errour fury breedes,
When wronges our mindes oppresse.
These treason working mates, still worke our great distresse.
Examples make us bolde.
To tread the doubtfull way,
Which we before were tolde,
Would lead us quite astray .
Perswations kindly mooue,
And winne us to do ill:
Whose poyson when we prooue,
We poysoned, love it still,
But iniury more strong,
Doth fiercely us incite:
By suffring to do wronge,
Forgetfull of the right,
All these thrice vertuous Queene, assaile thee with their might.
Who can vile deedes despise,
And flattering tongues neclect:
With malice temporize,
As wisedome doth direct.
Giue him the lawrell crowne,
Triumphant victors were:
The tytles of renowne,
Which vertues monarkes beare.
And thou most glorious queene,
These traytor foes repell:
That vertue may be seen,
In that your sexe to dwell.
And brauely vaunt thy worth where he most basely fel.
You haughty Lords, that bury death and fate,
In living monuments of lofty fame:
Whose worthy praise doth claime the boundles date,
wherewith eternity doth blaze her name.
Gainst whom raise you these forces in such haste?
Gainst whom lead you this danger threatning power?
Doth hatefull Hanniball your confines waste?
Or Brennus sword your lives seeke to deuoure:
No no my Lords, this your concea'ld designe,
Resounding Echoes of most strange debate:
With tragike tydinges fill'd these ears of mine,
That powr'd on me the storme of all your hate.
Never since princelie hande of Sylvias son,
Laide the foundations of these stately towers:
Did sharpe mischaunce so much eclyps the sunne,
Of our good fortune, with such fatall lowers.
But if that wisedome ever found a place,
Within your soules, which beautifies your praise:
Now shew the same, and saue from high disgrace,
Our bleeding honor, and death breathing ioyes.
You know how bloud maintaines the life of warres,
As doubtfull as dear bought the victory:
Mans destiny is chain'd by vnknowne starres,
To happy ioyes or mournfull misery.
If you triumph, you conquer not your foes,
But neighbors, kinsefolkes and your dearest friendes:
Whose wounds bleed shame, and deep hart-peircing woes,
Insteed of conquest this is your amendes.
But if my Lord obtaine the lawrell wreath,
And fortune smile on him with like successe:
What fatall tempests, furious rage will breath,
From his hearts caue, yourselves may easily guesse.
You know when touch of honor wings his minde,
What lyon thoughts tyre on his haughty soule.
Where wronged valour raignes it is hard to finde,
Such pitty as may honors pride coutroule.
Then sith your course to loose yourselves is bent,
To loose your lives or purchase living shame:
Let wisedomes eyes, blinde errours faults preuent,
With ease a sparke, with paine is quencht a flame.
Be aduocates for me to Caesars grace,
And stop in time the current of his hate:
Let gentle pittie in your mindes finde place,
When swords have pleaded, words will come too late.
You know my fortune ever hath been such,
As dazeled Envies eies with honors shine:
But since Antonius hath augmented much,
This soueraignty and great estate of mine;
Since nature, fortune, birth and maiesty,
In fields of glory stirre up ciuill warres,
Which of them most should raise my dignity,
And lift mine honor neerest to the starres;
Since these two Emperours whose princely hands,
Do sway the scepter of the Romaine state:
The one my brother, linkt in natures bands,
The other is my spouse and loving mate;
Since heauens themselves did in my life prouide,
To shew the map of their felicityes:
This Roome my Lords and all the world beside,
Make me the obiect of their wondring eyes.
Thus I that was more happy than the rest,
And did excell in glory and renoune:
With more than most disgrace shall be supprest,
No fall like his that falleth from a crowne.
And that which nature grantes the meanest wight,
They cannot loose which have the conquest wonne:
Yet with this strange Dylemma workes my spight,
Whosoever winne Octavia is vndone.
Great Empresse, this bright sunne can witnes well,
So can these heauens before whose powers I stand:
That against our mindes Caesar doth us compell,
This enterprize you see, to take in hand.
But for myself, and if the case be such,
That but report is auctor of this iarre:
If Caesars honor may be free from touch
Of any staine, relinquishing the warre.
I will do my best, and what I may perswade,
To lay down armes, wherein if I preuaile:
A perfect league of friendship shall be made,
That may the fury of this tempest quaile.
And pardon me dear soueraigne)though my speech
Include exceptions in this doubtfull wise:
I may not Caesar mooue, nor him beseech,
What may his maiestie disroyallize.
This said, behold my hand, my sword, my soule,
Here humbly prostrate at your princely feete:
What you commaund let none dare to controule,
This Caesar will and this we think most meete,

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: Madam, your speech I think doth not extend,
To the disparagement of your own bloud:
And sooner shall my life have finall end,
Than I refuse to do your highnes good.
Though last my speech, yet second unto none
Is my desire, to effectuate your will:
But lo where Caesar comes himself alone,
Arme we our tongues with words, our words with skil.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Fayer issue of renoun'd Octavius race,
My second self, Roomes glorious Empresse:
Behold us all assembled here in place,
To worke your safety and your wrongs redresse.
Your Lord Antonius as we hear)doth threate,
To power sharpe stormes of deep reuenging Ire,
Upon our heads:and make the imperial seate
His sole possession, ere he hence retyre.
But let him know, though finely he pretend,
To guilde iniustice with a Princes name:
Though he triumph in words, yet ere I end,
What he begins, he may repent the same.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: My gracious Lord, high words do but encrease
The flame of vallour in incensed mindes:
Leaue armes my Lord, and let us treate of peace:
Who best doth speed in war, smal safety findes,
Ful well the world your noble worth hath known,
Let not new dangers needlesse tropheies raise.
Let not the effect of hateful deeds be showne,
Against my Lord who may deserue your praise.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Shall he be prais'd that is become our foe,
Staine of our name, foile of the Romaine state:
A seruile man, contriuer of our woe,
And from all honor doth degenerate?
Nay what is more, it is said he doth pretend,
To worke our ruine, and our fatal end.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Can foule suspition then, and false report,
In wisedomes confines holde so large a place:
That it can foyle our reason in such sort,
To fly the good, and worke his own disgrace?
The auncient Romaines wont to draw their swordes,
To purchase honor, of their stoutest foes:
But you whose groundes are vaine surmized words,
By seeking honor, shall your honors loose.
Fame hath two wings, the one of false report:
The other hath some plumes of veritie;
Why then should doubtful rumour, raise a forte
Of mortall hate, against my Lord and me.
Suppose he rais'd as you have done, a power:
He to defend, not to offend his friend,
The heauens forbid that any fatall hower,
Should your proceedings turne to unhappy end.
Vnhappy no, he never falles amisse,
That foiles his foe before his final ende:
High honor, not long life, the treasure is,
Which noble mindes without respect defend.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: The prize of honor is not always bloud.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: It is honor all whose end imports our good.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: O wretched state where men make haste to dye.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: True valour feeles nor griefe nor misery.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: He is your brother, be not then vnkinde.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: Iustice, not pitty, fits a Princes minde.

sp.speaker: Oct,
sp.l: He hath done nothing, spare an innocent.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: He doth too much that beares a false entent.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: You both are stronge and both will buy it dear.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: I arm'd with iustice, know not how to fear.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: O Caesar shall my heart be made a stage,
For you to play a bloudie tragedie?
Shall fearce misfortune, breathing spitefull rage,
Make me vicegerent of all misery?
If both of you misled in errours maze,
Do seeke reuenge of misconceiued wrongs,
For your own sakes out of your fancies raze,
The spots of mallice grafted with your tongues.
But if mischance have offered disgrace,
To either party:O let me entreate,
That for my sake, kinde pardon may deface,
A fault so small, with breath of words made great.

sp.speaker: Caes
sp.l: Bright lamp of vertue, honors living flame,
Whosoever winne, you can no losse sustaine:
Whom partiall fortune list to crowne with fame,
His be the day, the triumph and the gaine.
The victor must be either your own Lord,
Or else your brother, who will both consent,
To trie their fortunes with the dinte of sword.
But shield you as the worlds chiefe ornament.
If both we fall, (which hap the heauens, forbid)
All that suruiue, are subiect to your will.
Your birth, your state, your vertues are not hid:
But known, and loved, and will be honored still.
No ear so deaf which hath not heard your name;
Whose eares have heard, their mindes your worth admire
Whose minds admire, their harts love doth enflame,
And winnes them subiect to your own desire.
No perils threaten you, you need not fear.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: But many you, and I their burthen beare.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: It is reason I, none else my griefes sustaine.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Where nature forceth, reason is but vaine.
And therefore Caesar here I thee beseech,
By these same scepter-bearing hands of mine:
By these same teares, true witnes of my speech;
By that same princely port and grace of thine;
By all the love thou bearest to Acctaes ghost,
By all the rightes that loving mindes hold dear;
Lay armes aside dismisse this puisant hoast,
Let friendly truce release my minde of fear.
If not, I will drowne my life in these same teares,
And tyre with plaints the Pandionian birdes:
Tyre the Halciones with griefe that beares
Too high a straine, for highest clyming words.
I will make the sunne for pitty cloath his steedes
In sorrows liuery, and disdaine your sight:
Force niggard Pluto with my wofull deeds,
To entertaine my soules disgraced flight.
Else will I flie and shrowde my face from shame,
Where Pyndus hides his head amongst the starres:
Or where ambitious Othris wanting flame
Of heauenly lamps, the cloudes swift motion barres.
Ought will I do, before these eies behold
Death's vissage painted in that princelie face:
Before I will see captiuitie, lay holde
On those fair lims, which merit highest grace.
Before I will see their bloudie weapons drinke,
The nectar of thy life, or Iuorie stain'd,
With vgly gore:O let me never think,
Or hope till then, to have this life maintain'd.
Before that time, death is a welcome guest
To my lives lodging:and O sisters dear,
If ever pitty dwelt in dyrefull brest,
Draw not my threed till that newes peirce mine eare.
How oft when sleep inuites my drowsie eye,
With natures curtaine to repell the light:
And hide my minde from sorrows tyranny,
Under the darknes of the silent night?
Shall thy pale ghost defil'd with deaths foule hand,
Stand in my sight, as in the cleerest day:
And fury-like arm'd with blacke fiery brand;
Affright my minde and chase dead sleep away?
Which being gone, fierce sorrows cruell clawes,
Seaze on my waking thoughts like tygers fell:
And gripe my heart with sharpe tormenting pawes,
That thousand times deaths rygour doth excell.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: O perfect vertue gracing woman kinde,
Inuincible Octavia cease to plaine:
O had Antonius half so good a minde,
No discord could betwixt us two remaine.
My Lords what think you, how may we proceed?
High honor cries reuenge upon our foes:
And yet Octavia crossing this our deed,
Cannot resolue which of us she would loose.

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.l: I think it is a braue and Princely thing,
With fire and sword to ruinate our foes:
But greater glory is it for a King,
To saue his subiects from wars common woes.
It is wisedome noble Caesar, must aduance
Our state beyond the reach of fortunes arme:
Not fierce reuenge which workes effectes by chance,
And glories most when most it worketh harme.
And valour, such as doth contemne all fear,
And guild our actes with honor and renowne:
With gentle clemencie, our deeds endeare,
And mount with vertue where chance throwes us down.

sp.speaker: Mecae.
sp.l: The rarest thing a Princes fame to raise,
Is to excell those that are excellent:
All other to surmount in vertues praise,
And be his kingdomes chiefest ornament.
Make quiet peace within his coastes remaine,
And succour those that live in great distresse:
From bloudy slaughter ever to refraine,
With time, and wisedome, passions rage suppresse.
These are the wings directing vertues flight.
This is the fuell feeding honors flame.
This is the path that leades to heauen aright.
and sun-bright beames that guild braue Caesars name.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Pitty my Lords, is often like a maske,
That hides our eyes from seeing what is iust:
Inuiting any to undertake the taske,
To worke our woes and execute their lust.
For to neclect the course we have begun,
Were to betray ourselves unto our foes:
Where keeping stronge though no exploite be done,
Yet gaining nothing, nothing shall we loose.
Why you are ill inform'd of Antony
And his attempts exceed your knowledge far:
I fear me when you know as much as I,
You will pleade as fast to prosecute the warre.
But see a stranger hasts into our sight,
With further newes, and if I iudge a right.

sp.speaker: Byl.
sp.l: Thrice noble Caesar hither am I sent,
Hauing in charge from great Mark Antony
The ambassage of his pleasure to present,
Before Octavia and thy maiesty.
First he commaunds Octavia to depart,
Out of his house, and leaue all that is his:
The reason why, he list not to impart,
It must suffice that such his pleasure is.
He likewise will, thy highnesse knowledge take,
How much he scornes thou shouldst his will withstad
And thereof meanes with fire and sword to make,
A perfect demonstration out of hand.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Will Antony our confines then inuade,
With Ciuill warres, contriuer of our woe?
Great reason preparation should be made,
For to withstand so puisant a foe.

sp.speaker: Byl.
sp.l: Fiue hundreth saile of warlike ships he brings,
Wherewith the froathing Ocean he scoures:
And in his army are eight forraigne Kings,
Eight Kings in person with their mighty powers.
A hundred thousand well arm'd foote, are led
Uner Canidius their chiefe generall:
Twelue thousand horse most strongly furnished,
All these are known, and known these are not all.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: How now my Lords, is this think you a time,
To talk of clemencie?or of delay?
Is not this mischiefe in his chiefest prime,
Before we could the speedie spring bewray?
What faith Octavia to these tidings strange,
Are our coniectures upon falshood grounded?
Can this suffice your setled thoughts to change?
Are not our lives with mischiefes Ocean bounded?

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Had I so many tongues to paint my woes,
As ever silent night had shining eyes:
