Yet could not all their eloquence disclose,
The throwes of greefe which do my minde surprize.
But would to God, this world of misery,
Mought presently be trebled unto me:
So that from imminent calamitie,
My deerest brother Caesar mought be free.
For me, long since I well discern'd the storme,
And sought by all meanes how I mought preuent it:
But sith no wit can Antony reforme,
O it is not I, but he, that will repent it.
I fear'd the stroke before I felt the wound,
But now resolu'd the worst of chance to bide:
True fortitude doth in my soule abound,
My honor scornes the height of fortunes pride.
The worst that can befall me is but death:
And O how sweete is his lives sacrifize,
On vertues altar that expires his breath,
And in the armes of innocencie dyes.
They only fear, and only wretched are,
From whose bad lives staind with impietie:
Their dying fame doth to the world declare,
Most shamefull stories of foule infamie.
But those that know not, let them learne in me:
That vertuous minds can never wretched be.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: My Lords, I will ye presently proclaime
Marke Antony a foe unto our state:
That all his soueraignties ye straight reclaime,
And all his dignities annihillate.
We will not see the Romaine Empires shine,
By any seruile minde to be defamed:
To manage steele our nature doth encline,
Of womens wanton toyes we are ashamed.
And therefore with such haste , as may be-fit,
A matter that imports our dearest bloud:
We will meet Antonius if the heauens permit,
And what we say, there will we make it good.
Adiew Octavia and yourself prepare
To runne what course of fortune I approue:
If happie starres to us alotted are,
I will never be forgetfull of your love.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Honour attend thy steps, and till I see,
The period of my worlds declining state:
I will never to myself a traytor be,
But seeke the meanes to stay your mortall hate.
Earth-ruling heauenly powers,
Great Ioues immortall mates:
That from your Chrystall bowers,
Dyrect all mortall states,
And us like Actors do dispose:
To play what parts you list to impose .
Must we, poore we, consent
To call you ever iust?
Though you our harts torment,
Even after your own lust?
And for each drop of hoped ioy:
Powre down whole tempests of annoy.
And that which is much more,
Looke what we best do deeme:
Doth vex our mindes more sore,
Than that we least esteeme.
And that which nature saith is best:
By tryall yeelds us smallest rest.
Who doth not wish, to weare
The terrour breeding crowne:
And direfull scepter beare,
As badge of high renoune?
Yet who more iustly do complaine:
That they the brunt of woes sustaine.
Stand who so list for me,
In highest slipperie place:
Though great their glorie be,
Yet greater their disgrace.
And who so subiect to mischance:
As those whom fortune doth aduance.
These base earth-creeping mates,
Proud enuie never spyes:
When at the greatest states,
Her poysoned quiuer flyes.
Each tempest doth turmoyle the seas:
When little lakes have quiet ease.
Not those that are bedight,
With burnisht glistering gould,
Whose pompe doth steale our sight,
With wonder to behoulde:
Tast smallest sweet without much gaule:
Nor finde true ioyes within their call.
This did the heauens impose,
Not that they are vniust:
But for to punish those,
Who glory in their lust.
And our misdeeds procure us still:
To seeke our good amongst much ill.
A monster honour is,
Whose eyes are vertues flame:
His face contempt of this,
Which we pale death do name.
His Lyon heart nought else doth fear:
But crowing cock of shame to hear.
His wings are high desires,
His feete of Iustice frame:
Food dangerous aspires,
His seate immortall fame.
only the traine of Enuies plumes,
With others growthe itself consumes.
Hath Geminus beheld the Aegyptian Queene,
The auctor of the troubled worlds distresse?
Hast thou her guifts and rare perfections seen,
That makes Antonius scences thus digresse?
Tell us, is she so admirable fair,
That Italy hath none which may come nigh her?
Doth she all beauties else so much impaire,
Or else indeed, doth partiall fame be lye her?
Have those her eyes so rare an influence,
To houlde and captiuate mens sences so,
That foyling wit, and reasons best defence,
They rauished, must needs themselves forgoe?

sp.speaker: Gem.
sp.l: I know not what may seem fair in your sight,
Because some like what others discommend:
But for myself, and if I iudge aright,
Speaking of Cleopatra as a frend.
The fairest thing that in her may be seen:
Is, that she is a Ladie and a Queene.
Madame, that sun-burnt coast, yeelds not a face
Which with the Romain beauties may compare:
There mought be found a thousand in this place;
Whose naturall perfections are more rare.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: How passing strange it seems that Antony
Should leaue the paragon of natures pride:
And follow her whose shamefull luxurie,
Doth make the world his folly to deride.
Whence should it spring that such a thing should be?
Is this his folly, or the heauens decree?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: His fault no doubt, and;crosseth natures lawes.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And I think not, for nature is the cause.
By nature we are moou'd, nay forst to love:
And being forst, can we resist the same?
The powerfull hand of heauen we wretches prooue:
Who strike the stroke, and poore we, beare the blame.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Loue sure, from nature took his birth by right,
But love of what?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Of beautie loves delight.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: And what is beautie?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: First say what is love?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Love is a desire of what doth liking moue.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Desire doth spring, from what we wish, and want,
Doth loose himself in winning of his saint:
Enioying doth that humor quite supplant,
And therefore cannot this loves nature paint.
If love were a desire, as you do guesse,
Sith none desires that which he doth enioy,
We could not love the thing we do possesse:
For why, enioying, would our love destroy.
But this is false, and you have iudg'd amisse.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Speak you the truth, whose iudgment better is.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I think this love a deepe affection sure,
Wrought by the instinct of natures hidden might,
Which in our hearts an vnion doth procure,
With that which perfect seems unto our sight.
Such is that love which in us doth arise,
When such a beautie we do chaunce to see:
As with our nature best doth simpathize,
Which nature, faultie is, and not poore we.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Well , what is beauty?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: That which liketh best.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Which liketh whom ?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Someone above the rest.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Why? some do like what others disalowe.
Some love, what others hate:and few there are
In whom a like affection doth growe,
Of any one thing, though the same be rare.
Were beautie then such as you here do name,
One thing should be, and not be beautifull,
One thing should be, and yet not be the same:
And that methinks were strange and wonderfull.
I rather think these outward beauties growe,
From iust proportion and right symmetrie:
Of these same guifts which nature doth bestow,
Upon us all in our natiuitie.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Indeed we see a mixture far more fine
In some, than others, wrought by natures frame:
To whom the praise of beautie we assigne,
Yet do not all alike affect the same.
Now, if this were the obiect of our love,
We all should like some one that were most fair:
Who should alone most deepe affection mooue,
Whil's vulgar minds mought drown in deep despaire.
But as no woman easily can endure,
To be depriu'd of beauties louely praise:
So is there none so much deformed sure,
That in some minds, affection doth not raise.
There is none so fair whose beautie all respect,
Although we were enforst it should be so:
Some nothing fair, whom we must needs affect,
Though reason, wit, and all the world say no.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: And what should be the cause of all this same?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I think because we lodge in natures frame.
Look how the Loadstone draws nought else but steele
Though mettals far more pretious are about it:
Yet this as his fit subiect seems to feele
His power attractiue, and mooues not without it,
Or as in diuerse instruments we see,
When anyone doth strike a tuned string:
The rest which with the same in concord be,
Will shew a motion to that sencelesse thing;
When all the other neither stirre nor playe,
Although perhaps more musicall than they:
So are our minds, in spight of reasons nay,
Strain'd with the bent of natures sympathie:
Whose powerfull force, no wit, no art, can stay.
And if you ask a farther reason why:
In these two things, but shew the cause of both:
And then I will tell you why we love, and loathe.
Now, if the power of nature be so strong
That even sencelesse things yeeld thereunto:
O why should we endure so great a wrong,
To beare the blame of that which others do.
What living man can ceasse himself to be,
And yet as possible as to refraine,
From that whereto our nature doth agree:
And spight of us, doth us thereto constraine.
Who can be angry with the sencelesse steele,
For cleauing unto this hard-harted thing?
Or blame that which can neither hear, nor feele,
For moouing to the other sounding string.
If these may be excusd by natures lawes:
O how much more should we be free from blame,
Within whose tender hearts affection drawes,
Such deepe caractars leading to the same.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Is beautie then, sole obiect of our love?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: That which seems so, doth our affection moue.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I ever thought that vertue had been best.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: We praise that most, but yet esteeme it least.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Why disestemd, whose worth is so well known.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: To shew that vice the world hath ouergrowne.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: The name is often hard in each mans mouth.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: The thing more rare than Eagles in the south.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: The thing contemnd can we the name esteeme?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Yes all that are not such as all would seem.
But sith this is the beautie of the minde,
And nothing fits our naturall discourse:
Let us excuses for Antonius finde,
And to our former purpose have recourse.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: No Iulia no, your haruest is too long,
For such a simple croppe as you receiue:
You may not thus persist the truth to wrong,
And with your wit, the world seeke to deceiue.
But Lord how willing are we to inuent,
And finde out couerts to obscure our sinne:
As though to hide the same, and not repent,
Could us preserue from being drownd therein.
It is true, that nature did these buildings frame.
And true, that they to natures power are thrall.
And true, that imperfections foyle the same.
And true, that we by natures weaknesse fall.
And this is true, that God vnnatured all,
And gave us wisdome to suppresse our will:
He gave us perfect reason to recall,
Affections scoutes from following what is ill.
Why we are men: and this same sparke diuine,
Our trouping thoughts should marshall in such wise,
That no affect from reason should decline,
Nor rebell passion in our hearts arise.
The instinct of nature, which doth all things moue,
Bids love whereas you like without regarde:
But pietie saith, where it is lawfull love,
Or else hell torments shall be your rewarde.
And is it true, is Antony vnkinde?
Hath this new love, of faith and troath bereft him?
Can fonde affection so obscure his minde,
That not one sparke of honor should be left him?
Can he so far forget his own good name,
As to dishonor all that are about him?
Ah can he not without a further blame,
Permit them dye that cannot live without him?
Come poore companions of my misery,
The issue of the faithlest man aliue:
Support the burthen of his trecherie,
Whose base reuoult, our ruine doth contriue.
Come poore beholders of your mothers fall,
Whose innocence mought greater pittie moue:
Your impious father doth despise us all,
Forsaken we, must other fortunes proue.
Come poore attendants of a falling state,
Whose silent sadnesse doth my greefe renue:
Yet be you all much more vnfortunate,
Ere any seedes of leawdnesse rest in you.
Come let us go, and leaue this loanly place,
Your fathers dying love bequeaths you hence:
O flye this house, as from your own disgrace,
It is his commaund you should be banishtt hence,
Dead fulvia how can thy imperious ghoast
Endure to see thine Orphants thus oppressed?
Yet of mine honor though his love be lost,
Whiles I suruiue, they shall not be distressed.
O Antony borne of no gentle Syre,
Some cruell Caucasus did thee beget:
Even scencelesse things thy scencelesnesse admire,
And seem to feele, what thou seemst to forget.
Oft have I seen these stones with pitty moued,
Sheed dropping teares, lamenting my disgrace:
When in thy heart where most it most behoued,
No kinde remorse could ever finde a place.
More milde than thee, I finde each cruell beast,
For they but give a smale-time lasting death:
With endlesse greefe, my soule thou dost molest,
Which ever killing, never stops my breath.
O failing piller of my falling state!
O fading flower of vertues fairest field!
O why shouldst thou so much degenerate,
And honors byrth-right to dishonor yeeld.
Yeeld to dishonour all that dear bought wealth,
Which earthly kings doth in heauens kingdom place.
Let thy mindes treasure fall away by stealth,
By stealth contriue and worke thine own disgrace.
O Erecina that my Lord did know,
As thy fonde boye shootes shaftes of swift desire:
So mightie Iove sharpe thunder-boults doth throwe,
Confounding such as from his lawes retyre.
He nurst in sinne, sees not his own disgrace,
Augmenting still, our sorrow and his shame:
That greatnesse hides the danger from his face,
But yet my care is doubled with the same.
The greedie Wolfe, and cruell rauening beare,
Toucht with the extremity of hungrie paine,
The guiltlesse cattle furiously do teare:
And being fed, from crueltie refraine.
But tyranizing greefe prayes on the heart,
And cloyed with sighes and teares doth still perseuer:
His raging furie nothing may diuert,
But still, still fed, is satisfied never.
O happie he, a thousand times and more,
Whose quiet thoughts so milde a calme do gaine:
That neither hope can force from safeties shore,
Nor deepe despaire can sincke on mischiefes maine.
But maiestie, and honour, for these too,
Shall be the only obiects of mine eye:
What vertue saith is iust, that will I do,
Thus I resolue to live, thus will I dye.
And are you sure that Antony is slaine?
May we beleeue that this report is true?

sp.speaker: Byl.
sp.l: Why should you wish me to recount again,
The story that doth double greefe renue?
O had you but discouered with your eyes,
The face of woe in all that present were:
Or heard their dolefull noyse and shriking cryes,
You would have cause to greeue and not to fear.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: What tragick tidings bring these wofull wights,
That ring such peales of horror in mine eares?
What vnknowne cause your martiall hearts affrights?
What silent greefe in your sadde looks appeares?

sp.speaker: Byl.
sp.l: Did but our words import the sound of woe,
To wound your eares withall were double sinne:
But sithe your highnesse will, it should be so,
And that your safetie is contain'd therein;
We will not from your grace conceale the same;
And though we should, yet time will open all.
From AEgipts common woes I lately came,
And did bewaile Antonius wilfull fall.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Is Antony ore'throwne?

sp.speaker: Byl.
sp.l: Yes all is lost.
His power and forces wholy are decayed:
He is deceiued by her he loued most,
By cleopatra shamefully betrayed.
And she that taught him first to swim in sinne:
Was even the first that drown'd his life therein.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Ah, by what meanes did she my Lord abuse?

sp.speaker: Byl.
sp.l: By such a meanes as leawd offenders vse.
For when the warres at first pretended were,
And that Antonius with him would not take her:
She fearing lest herself not being there,
He haply mought be moued to forsake her.
She fees Canidius our cheefe Generall,
Him to perswade, that she mought present be:
He sues, obtaines, and we embarked all,
Make ioyfull haste our wofull end to see.
For whilst our powers of equall forces were;
And neither side could disaduantage spye:
Like one that knew a secret cause of fear,
Out of the armie she began to flye.
Loe, how no greatnesse can our conscience free,
From inward horror of our wicked deeds:
For that same better part of us doth see,
A greater power whose Iustice terrour breeds.
But he, whose thoughts were to her looks enchained,
Although the armie did no losse sustaine,
As though for her he had the world disdayned:
Forsakes them all, and after flyes amaine.
Whose causelesse fear so much dismaid the hoast,
Who scorn'd to fight for him which runne away:
That with small hurt, the battle there was lost,
And Caesar had the honor of the day.
The Legions, thus depriued of a guide,
Themselves to Caesars clemencie submit:
Antonius basenesse they do all deride,
And think a chamber were for him more fit.
But Lyon-harted Caesar still proceeds,
His strength is doubled, weakened is his foe:
Unto Pelusium hastely he speedes,
These fugitiues may not escape him so.
There lay Antonius nauie in the rode,
Who yeelded when Augustus fleet was seen:
And likewise shewed how Antony abode,
At Alexandria with this fearfull Queene,
Who seeing thus himself depriued of ayde,
Cryes out that Cleopatra hath betrayed him:
She whether guiltie, or perhaps affraid,
That from her slaughter nothing could have staid him;
Flies from his sight, and falsely sends him word,
That she (drownd in despaire)herself had slaine:
Wherwith enrag'd, he takes a bloudie sword,
And breathing out these speeches all in vaine;
O Cleopatra princesse of my heart;
And art thou dead? lo dying I adore thee:
This more than death, doth now procure my smart,
That wanting courage, I went not before thee;
With that, yet warme death-couloured instrument,
In his fair brest he did the gate set ope,
Which to the earth, his bloudlesse lims hath sent:
His dying soule up to the heauens I hope.
And is he dead?

sp.speaker: Byl.
sp.l: His better part yet liueth,
But to his corps a tombe sweet quiet giueth

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: O poore Promethius now I feele thy paines,
Greefes greedie vulture feedes upon my heart:
Upon my head a shower of mischiefe raines,
And all the heauens conclude to worke my smart.
O my Antonius O my Lord, my Lord:
O that Octavia had been slaine for thee;
O that the heauens would unto me afford,
That this my bloud mought thy lives ransome be.
Mine was the wound thou gauest that noble brest,
That purple streame extracted from my heart:
In my deepe passions is thy death exprest,
Thou feltst the stroke, but I endure the smart,
And O that greefe did not thus stop my breath,
And all my words dissolue in showers of teares,
That I mought worthily lament thy death:
And Catadupa-like, dull all mens eares.
Vnhappy world, the pilgrimage of paine,
The stage where mischiefe actes a dyreful part:
What hast thou had, what dost thou now containe,
Which but a thought of pleasures mought impart.
Not one care-wanting hour my life hath tasted:
But from the very instant of my birth,
Vncessant woes my tyred heart have wasted,
And my poore thoughts are ignorant of mirth.
Looke how one waue, another still pursueth,
When some great tempest holds their troups in chase:
Or as one hour an others losse reneweth;
Or posting day supplyes anothers place;
So do the billows of affliction beate me,
And hand in hand the stormes of mischiefe go;
Successiue cares with vtter ruine threate me;
Griefe is enchain'd with griefe, and woe with woe,
Yet must I beare it with a patient minde:
For why the heauens have this to me assign'd.
Inexorable fates,
That on both high and low,
Your equall rigour shew:
Correcting all estates,
And stately mindes suppressing.
Your fauour none may winne,
No cloake or faults can hide:
But needs we must abide,
The punishment of sinne,
And hope for no releasing.
No greatnes may withstand,
No words can pitty mooue:
But we must all approoue,
The vigour of your hand:
Great Ioues decrees expressing.
Great Ioues decrees, which some,
Fate, fortune, chance, do name:
Are not indeed the same,
But heauens eternall doome,
Our witlesse steps directing.
Their speech exceedes our skill,
Their words pierce not our eares:
But in our life appeares,
The legent of their will:
Our errours misse correcting.
Then let the greatest know,
Dole on their ruine feedes:
Whiles they obscure vile deedes,
Under a glorious shew;
The vulgar sort infecting.
Octauia still distrest,
Doth not to us declare,
How they most wretched are,
Who are with griefe opprest:
But shewes what heauen requireth.
How through affliction great,
Great troubles and annoy:
We finde the doubtfull way,
That leades to vertues seate:
Which wisedomes self desireth.
In fairest christall stone,
Let men her tropheys shew:
That all the world may know,
Here liueth such a one,
As vertues height asspireth.
Sharpe griefe and sweet delight,
Are Gyants to approoue:
If aught may us remoue,
And turne us from the right,
Thence double errour springeth.
The weakest wrought his fall,
Whiles that Octauia true:
The other did subdue.
And purchast therewithall:
That fame her honor singeth.
A monument most rare,
Of pure Arabian gold,
The highest worth to unfold ,
Let art for her prepare:
Who time in tryumph bringeth.
Time shall endeare thy name,
With honors breath make sweet:
The garland is most meete,
For such as winne the same;
Thy vertue best deserued.
Whiles any sparke of worth,
Doth lodge in womans brest:
Thy praise among the rest,
Be euermore henceforth,
In noblest mindes preserued:
Of Diamonds most pure,
A tombe let Angels frame:
And there engraue her name,
For euermore to endure ,
To eternity reserued.

body.stage: L'aqua non temo de l'eterno oblio.

sp.l: Our Play is done, now what your censures are,
If with, or against Arts industrie, the care
Tooke by the Author and our paines to please)
We know not yet, until judgement give us ease.
Why should we doubt? this Theater does appeare
The Musicke Rome of concord; you being here.
Let no barsh jarring sound of discord then,
Echo dislike;claps crowne the Tragicke Pen.
